parse.title: List of alternative therapies for developmental and learning disabilities

text.*:
This list covers alternative therapies for developmental and learning disabilities. Many of the treatments—including physiotherapy, massage and others—are neither generally considered as 'alternative therapies' nor as standard treatments for developmental and learning disabilities. They are, however, sometimes given or recommended as treatments specifically for these disabilities and therefore included in the list. None of these therapies are supported by scientific evidence.[1]

Contents

  • 1 Bioenergy therapies
  • 2 Dietary treatments
  • 3 Eclectic approaches
  • 4 Hearing therapies
  • 5 Holistic healing
  • 6 Medical interventions
  • 7 Movement-based therapies
  • 8 Pedagogical approaches and policies
  • 9 Psychosocial interventions
  • 10 Stress management
  • 11 Student profiling
  • 12 Technological interventions
  • 13 Touch therapies
  • 14 Training methods
  • 15 Visual approaches
  • 16 Emerging therapies
  • 17 References
  • 18 External links

Bioenergy therapies[edit]

  • Bi-Aura therapy[2][3]
  • Craniosacral therapy[3]
  • Distant healing[2]
  • Electromagnetic Field (EMF) Balancing Technique[2]
  • magnetic field therapy[3]
  • therapeutic touch (TT)[3] According to the American medical association,therapeutic touch is "little more than quackery".[4]
  • Thought Field Therapy (TFT)[3]
  • [1] program practices for social development[5]
  • Alexander technique[2]
  • Chiropractic[2]
  • Feldenkreis[2]
  • Osteopathy[2]
  • Physiotherapy and occupational therapy for learning disabilities[2]
  • Pilates[2]
  • Yoga[2]
  • Zero Balancing[2]

Dietary treatments[edit]

  • additive-free diets[2][3][6]
  • Antifungal medication[3]
  • Ayurvedic medicine[2]
  • B6-magnesium treatment[3]
  • Chelation therapy[3]
  • fatty acids[2][7]
  • Feingold Diet
  • food allergies, multiple chemical sensitivities (diet base)[2][6]
  • Gluten-free, casein-free diet (GFCF)[3]
  • glyconutritional supplement[7]
  • herbal medicine[2][3][6][7]
  • iron[2]
  • lutein-free diet[3]
  • megavitamins[3][6][7]
  • refined sugar-free diet[2][6]
  • secretin treatment[3]
  • trace minerals, trace elements[6][7]
  • vaccination (avoidance)[3]
  • zinc[2]

Eclectic approaches[edit]

  • Sunflower therapy[8]

Hearing therapies[edit]

  • Auditory integration training (AIT), auditory processing training[2][3][6]
  • Mozart Effect[7]
  • music therapy[2]
  • Spectral Activated Music of Optimal Natural Structure (SAMONAS)[2]
  • The Tomatis Method[2]

Holistic healing[edit]

  • Applied Kinesiology[6]
  • crystal therapy[2]
  • flower remedies[2]
  • homeopathy[2][3]
  • naturopathy[2][3]

Medical interventions[edit]

  • anti-motion sickness medication and other types for Vestibular Dysfunction[6]

Movement-based therapies[edit]

  • Brushing technique[2]
  • Developmental Exercise Programme (inhibition of primitive reflexes)[7]
  • Doman method[9]
  • (Psychomotor) patterning[3][6]
  • Dance Movement Therapy
  • Physio-Neuro Therapy[10]

Pedagogical approaches and policies[edit]

  • Full inclusion[3]
  • Gentle Teaching[3]
  • Person Centered Approach (PCA)[3]

Psychosocial interventions[edit]

  • Floortime (aka DIR)[3]
  • holding therapy[3]
  • TEACCH[3]

Stress management[edit]

  • caffeine-free diet[2]
  • Laughter therapy[2]
  • meditation[2]
  • positive thinking[2]
  • stress management[2]

Student profiling[edit]

  • Learning styles[7]

Technological interventions[edit]

  • Biofeedback[6]
  • Facilitated Communication[3]

Several scientific studies have shown that facilitated communication is quackery by proving that what the Autistic patient "says" is influenced entirely by the facilitater.[11]

  • Fast ForWord[3]

Touch therapies[edit]

  • acupressure[2]
  • acupuncture[2]
  • aromatherapy[2]


  • Bowen Technique[2]
  • Brushing and joint compression[3]
  • Emotional Freedom Technique[2]
  • massage[2][3]
  • reflexology[2]
  • Reiki[2]

Training methods[edit]

  • Positive behavior support (PBS)[3]
  • Sensory integration therapy (SIT)[3]
  • Whole Language[3]

Visual approaches[edit]

  • Asfedic Tuning (TintaVision)[7]
  • Coloured overlays[7]
  • Dunlop test[2]
  • Harris Filters[2]
  • Intuitive Colorimeter[2][7]
  • Irlen Syndrome[2]
  • Optim-Eyes[7]
  • Prism glasses[3]
  • Tinted lenses, ChromaGen lenses[2][6][7]
  • Visual Tracking Magnifier[2]

Emerging therapies[edit]

  • Dolphin Assisted Therapy[2]
  • Hypnotherapy[2]
  • Light and Colour Therapy[2]
